manuals, supplementary texts, and syllabuses to
help schools receiving the airborne courses. Teach¬
ers and officials of schools volunteering to use the
telecasts attended workshops at nineteen colleges
and universities. A separate summer-long work¬
shop was held at Purdue University for the air¬
borne-television teachers. They then dispersed to
six ETY stations to begin recording their courses.
Most of them will devote a full school year to
preparing 128 half-hour lessons. Because each
lesson may reach hundreds of thousands of stu¬
dents, the teachers have the aid of curriculum
specialists, research assistants, artists, and other
resources that not even the most affluent school
system could normally afford.
The project’s eventual expansion to broadcasting
over six channels, for a total of seventy-two half
hours a day, may come through the use of “nar¬
row-band” telecasting, a new method whereby
broadcasts occupy only three megacycles in the
television band instead of six, thus doubling the
number of telecasts possible in the same wave¬
length. Courses scheduled for the first year of air¬
borne telecasting on the school level include Span¬
ish, French, social studies, arithmetic for gifted
children, art, music, literature and composition,
history, geography, and science; on the college
level, chemistry, mathematics, and Russian.
On the basis of weather studies, experts estimate
that the airborne system will be able to operate
more than 95 per cent of the time.
